p: Abundance of fungal phyla also did not differ between native and non‐native Phragmites rhizosphere soil, although some common phyla differed among sites (Figure 2b). Soil saturation was a significant determinant of Mortierellomycota abundance (ANCOVA p < .001), such that it decreased in saturated soil ( r 2 = .404, p < .001; Appendix S1, Figure S3, Table S4). The majority of oomycete sequences recovered belonged to Pythiaceae. Site and lineage interacted marginally in affecting Pythiaceae abundance ( p = .076) as well as abundance of unclassified oomycetes ( p = .051). Soil saturation and plant host lineage significantly interacted in affecting Pythiaceae (ANCOVA p = .018) and unclassified oomycete relative abundance (ANCOVA p = .021) such that the non‐native lineage hosted slightly less Pythiaceae ( r 2 = .398, p = .016) and more unclassified oomycetes ( r 2 = .377, p = .011) in saturated sites (Appendix S1, Figure S4, Table S5). The phylogenetic resolution of our recovered sequences did not allow us to compare abundance of Pythiaceae genera or species between Phragmites lineages.
